summary: This is a legal reply memorandum filed by The New York Times Company in its FOIA lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The document argues that the BOP has failed to justify withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide under various FOIA exemptions (7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, and 7(E)). The Times seeks summary judgment to force disclosure of these records. This document is a court filing from The New York Times Company's legal team, arguing against the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) invocation of FOIA exemptions to withhold documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's death. It cites legal precedents and argues that suicide prevention procedures are publicly known and should be disclosed.

persons.name: David E. McCraw
persons.context: Lead counsel for The New York Times Company, submitting the court filing and arguing for disclosure of documents related to Epstein's death.

persons.name: Alexandra Settelmayer
persons.context: Listed as counsel for The New York Times Company in the FOIA lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate whose incarceration, suicide, and related records are the subject of the FOIA lawsuit. The document discusses records about his mental/physical health, suicide attempts, death, and visitor logs.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: A murder defendant who briefly shared a cell with Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC. The BOP cites his ongoing prosecution as a reason to withhold records under FOIA Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Kara Christenson
persons.context: A BOP official who submitted a declaration (the 'Christenson Decl.') in support of the government's motion to withhold documents. Her statements about law enforcement purposes and privacy interests are contested by The Times.

persons.name: Russell
persons.context: A BOP official (last name only provided) who submitted a supplemental declaration in support of the government's motion to withhold documents. His statements about witness interference are contested.

persons.name: Ali Watkins
persons.context: A New York Times journalist cited as the author of articles about Epstein's autopsy and last days, which are referenced to demonstrate public interest in the withheld records.

persons.name: Michael Gold
persons.context: A New York Times journalist co-author of an article on Epstein's autopsy results, cited to show public interest.

persons.name: Danielle Ivory
persons.context: A New York Times journalist co-author of an article on Epstein's last days, cited to show public interest.

persons.name: Christina Goldbaum
persons.context: A New York Times journalist co-author of an article on Epstein's last days, cited to show public interest.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: A Miami Herald journalist cited for an article quoting Epstein's brother calling for BOP to produce records, undermining the government's claimed privacy interest.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was involved in an apparent suicide attempt while incarcerated at the MCC. Records related to this event are among those being withheld by the BOP.

events.title: Epstein's Death by Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide, hanging himself in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: Filing of Reply Memorandum
events.description: The New York Times Company filed this reply memorandum in further support of its cross-motion for summary judgment in its FOIA lawsuit against the BOP.

events.title: Court Filing Submission
events.description: The New York Times Company's legal team files a document in court arguing for disclosure of BOP records related to Jeffrey Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, New York (MCC)
United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The BOP is withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide, citing FOIA Exemptions 7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, and 7(E).

The withheld records include emails about Epstein's mental/physical health, details of his incarceration, reports on his suicide attempt and death, correspondence with his cellmate's attorneys, and Epstein's medical/psychological records.

The BOP claims disclosure could interfere with the prosecutions of Nicholas Tartaglione (Epstein's former cellmate) and two correctional officers accused of failing to perform counts, but The Times argues the records are administrative and tangential.
The document reveals that visitor and phone logs for Epstein while in BOP custody are among the withheld records, which could show who had access to him.

The Times argues that the BOP has failed to demonstrate 'foreseeable harm' from disclosure as required by the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016, particularly for deliberative process claims under Exemption 5.
The document is a legal filing by The New York Times Company seeking to force the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) to disclose documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's death under FOIA.
It argues that BOP's invocation of FOIA exemptions is invalid because suicide prevention procedures are publicly known and detailed in Department of Justice publications.
The filing cites legal precedents (Coleman v. FBI, Shapiro v. Dep't of Justice) regarding when investigative techniques can be withheld from public disclosure.
It requests the court to order BOP to provide the requested documents within 20 business days and award The Times costs and attorneys' fees.
